question: Detailed description of meteorological information provided at the aerodrome and an indication of which meteorological office is responsible, is in the following part of the AIP
explanation: The Aerodrome (AD) section of the Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP) provides detailed information about individual aerodromes and heliports.
subject: Regulations

question: A checklist of AIP supplements currently in force shall be issued at intervals of:
explanation: AIP Supplements. Temporary changes of long duration (three months or longer) and information of short duration which contains extensive text and/or graphics are published as AIP supplements. Each AIP supplement is allocated a serial number which shall be consecutive and based on the calendar year. AIP supplement pages are kept in the AIP as long as all or some of their contents remain valid. When an AIP supplement is sent in replacement of a NOTAM, it is to include a reference to the serial number of the NOTAM. A checklist of AIP supplements currently in force is issued at intervals of not more than one month (i.e. monthly or more frequent). AIP supplement pages should be coloured in order to be conspicuous, preferably in yellow.
subject: Regulations

question: Which of the following is information that is not given in AIP approach and landing charts?
explanation: Visibility minima are not typically provided in the AIP approach and landing charts. Instead, these charts provide information such as Obstacle Clearance Height (OCH), Decision Altitude/Height (DA/H), Circling Clearance Altitude/Height (CCA), DME frequencies, and procedure details like headings and altitudes.
subject: Regulations

question: An integrated aeronautical information package consists of the following elements

choices.choice: AIP, supplements to AIP; NOTAM and PIB, AIC and checklist summaries
AIP, including amendment service; supplements to AIP, NOTAM and pre-flight information bulletin (PIB), ), AIC, checklists and summaries
AIP, including amendment service; supplements to AIP, NOTAM, AIC and checklist summaries

explanation:
The Integrated Aeronautical Information Package is a comprehensive system designed to disseminate critical information for aviation operations and safety. It includes the following elements:

  • Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP): Includes amendments and provides essential information for flight operations.
  • Supplements to the AIP: For temporary changes of long duration or extensive content.
  • NOTAM (Notice to Airmen) and Pre-flight Information Bulletins (PIBs): Provide time-sensitive, short-duration information for flights.
  • Aeronautical Information Circulars (AICs): Used to convey non-time-critical information that may affect flight safety or efficiency.
  • Checklists and Summaries: Provide current details on the status of aeronautical information, helping ensure that pilots and operators are using up-to-date information.
subject: Regulations

question: Temporary changes on specifications for AIP supplements of long duration and information of short duration which contains extensive text and/or graphics shall be published as AIP supplements. It is considered a long duration.
explanation:
AIP Supplements

  • Purpose: AIP Supplements are used to publish temporary changes of long duration (three months or longer) and information of short duration that requires extensive text and/or graphics.
  • Serial Numbering: Each AIP Supplement is assigned a consecutive serial number based on the calendar year for easy tracking and reference.
  • Validity: AIP supplement pages remain included in the AIP as long as all or some of their contents are valid, ensuring that users have access to relevant information.
subject: Regulations

question: Operationally significant changes to the AIP shall be published in the accordance with:

choices.choice: AIC procedures and identified by the acronym AIC followed by a number
NOTAM procedures and identified by acronym NOTAM followed by a number
AIRAC procedures and identified by the acronym AIRAC

explanation: AIRAC. Operationally significant changes to the AIP are published in accordance with Aeronautical Information Regulation and Control procedures and shall be clearly identified by the acronym – AIRAC. Each AIRAC AIP amendment page, including the cover sheet, must display an effective date.
subject: Regulations

question: A checklist of NOTAM currently in force shall be issued at the AFTN at intervals of:
explanation:
NOTAM Checklists

  • Issuance Frequency: A checklist of current NOTAMs is issued at intervals of not more than one month.
  • Reference Information: The checklist should refer to the latest AIP amendment, AIP supplement, and any internationally distributed Aeronautical Information Circulars (AICs).
subject: Regulations

question: Change in the frequency or location of navigational aids on short notice is notified through:
explanation:
NOTAM

  • Definition: NOTAMs are notices distributed via telecommunications that provide critical information regarding the establishment, condition, or changes in any aeronautical facility, service, procedure, or hazard.
  • Purpose: The timely knowledge of this information is essential for personnel concerned with flight operations, including pilots, air traffic controllers, and other aviation stakeholders.
subject: Regulations

question: The contents of Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP) are:
explanation:
AIP Structure

The AIP consists of three main parts:

  1. Part 1 – General (GEN):
    • Contains general information about aviation regulations, procedures, and services.
  2. Part 2 – En Route (ENR):
    • Provides information related to routes, navigation aids, and airspace usage for aircraft during flight between aerodromes.
  3. Part 3 – Aerodrome Data (AD):
    • Includes detailed information about individual aerodromes, such as facilities, runway specifications, and operational procedures.
subject: Regulations

question: The SIGMET service, is in the AIP, in the following part:
explanation:

subject: Regulations

question: In which chapter of the AIP can you find a list with “Location Indicators”?
explanation:

question: The information on holding, approach and departure procedures, are found in the following part of the AIP;
explanation:

question: The closure of a runway for a year, because of maintenance, will be published:

choices.choice: In NOTAM and AIP, inclusive Supplement

explanation: The closure of a runway for an extended period, such as a year due to maintenance, must be published in the Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP) as well as in NOTAMs. According to ICAO regulations, temporary changes of long duration (three months or longer) are published as AIP Supplements, while significant operational changes or temporary closures should also be promptly communicated through NOTAMs
subject: Regulations

question: AN AIRAC is:

choices.choice: An acronym for a system aimed at advance notification based on common effective dates, of circumstances necessitating significant changes in operating procedures

A notice distributed by means of telecommunication containing information concerning the establishment, condition or change in any aeronautical facility service, procedure or hazard, the timely knowledge of which is essential to personal concerned with flight operations
A package which consists of the following elements: AIP, supplements to the AIP, NOTAM, AIC, checklists and summaries

explanation: The AIRAC (Aeronautical Information Regulation And Control) system ensures that operationally significant changes to the AIP are published with common effective dates. These changes are issued 42 days in advance and must remain unchanged for at least 28 days following the effective date. The AIRAC schedule operates on a 28-day cycle and is designed for advance notification of changes in procedures, with a special provision for major changes allowing publication 56 days prior to the effective date.
subject: Regulations

question: Select the acronym corresponding to the following definition: an special NOTAM series notifying, by means of a specific format, an important change for the aircraft operations, due to a volcano activity, a volcano eruption or a volcanic ash cloud.
explanation: An ASHTAM is a special type of NOTAM issued for volcanic activity that may affect aviation. It alerts aircraft operators about volcanic eruptions, volcanic ash clouds, and associated hazards. The ASHTAM includes details such as the location of the volcanic activity, the time of the eruption, the height of the ash cloud, and its spread. ASHTAMs are part of the aeronautical information system and are distributed when there’s a significant volcanic threat to flight operations.
subject: Regulations

question: The system notifying in advance the circumstances requiring important changes in the methods of operation, based on common effective dates, is identified by the acronym:
explanation:
AIRAC

Information concerning establishment, withdrawal or significant changes upon a series of common effective dates at intervals of 28 days. The information notified therein shall not be changed further for at least another 28 days after the effective date, unless the circumstance notified is of a temporary nature and would not persist for the full period.
subject: Regulations

question: The temporary, long-term modification (3 months or more) and the short-term extensive or graphical information are published as follows:
explanation: AIP Supplements are used for temporary changes of long duration (three months or longer) or short-duration changes that include extensive text and/or graphics. Each supplement is given a consecutive serial number based on the calendar year and remains in the AIP for as long as the information is valid. This ensures that all relevant updates are available and that users are informed through a system of AIP amendments and trigger NOTAMs when changes are made.

question: A notice providing information on Rules of the Air, Traffic Services and Air Navigation Procedures and distributed in advance of its effective date is:
explanation:
AIRAC (Aeronautical Information Regulation and Control) is a standardized system designed to ensure the timely dissemination of significant operational changes in aviation. It establishes common effective dates for such changes, allowing all stakeholders to prepare and adapt accordingly.

Key features of AIRAC include:

  1. Advance Notification: AIRAC notices are distributed at least 42 days before the effective date of the change. This allows operators, pilots, and air traffic services to adjust their operations based on the new information.
  2. Regular Intervals: AIRAC amendments occur at regular 28-day intervals, ensuring that all changes are synchronized across the aviation community.
  3. Stability: Once published, AIRAC information must remain unchanged for at least 28 days following its effective date, unless the information is of a temporary nature.
  4. Comprehensive Coverage: The AIRAC system encompasses various types of aeronautical information, including changes in airspace structure, navigation aids, and procedures.
subject: Regulations

question: A notice containing information concerning flight safety, air navigation, technical, administration or legislative matters and originated at the AIS of a state is called:
explanation:
An AIC shall be originated whenever it is necessary to promulgate aeronautical information which does not qualify:
a) for inclusion in an AIP; or
b) for the origination of a NOTAM.

An AIC shall be originated whenever it is desirable to promulgate:
a) a long-term forecast of any major change in legislation, regulations, procedures or facilities;
b) information of a purely explanatory or advisory nature liable to affect flight safety;
c) information or notification of an explanatory or advisory nature concerning technical, legislative or purely administrative matters.
subject: Regulations

question: Each contracting state shall provide an Aeronautical Information Service (AIS) in its territory and for areas in which the state is responsible for the AIR Traffic Services outside its territory, and this shall include the preparation and origination of:
explanation: Each contracting state is required to provide an Aeronautical Information Service (AIS), which includes the preparation and origination of the Integrated Aeronautical Information Package (IAIP). This package comprises the Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP), Supplements to the AIP, NOTAMs and pre-flight information bulletins (PIBs), Aeronautical Information Circulars (AIC), Checklists and Summaries and AIRAC notices. This comprehensive approach ensures that all necessary aeronautical information is made available for effective air navigation and safety management.
subject: Regulations

question: The identification of each prohibited, restricted and danger area shall be composed by:

choices.choice: The nationality letters for location indicators assigned to the state or territory, followed the letters P, R and D are figures
The letters P (Prohibited), R (Restricted) and D (Dangerous) for the area concerned and figures
The letters P (Prohibited), R (Restricted) and D (Dangerous) followed by figures

explanation:
Prohibited, Restricted, and Danger Areas are crucial components of airspace management, designed to ensure flight safety. Within each state’s Flight Information Region (FIR), these areas are identified and monitored. Each area is assigned a unique designator that combines the country identifier, a letter indicating the type of area (P for Prohibited, R for Restricted, D for Danger), and a number ranging from 001 to 999.

For instance, in the UK, a danger area off the north coast of Cornwall is designated as EG D001, where EG represents the ICAO identifier for the UK, D indicates a danger area, and 001 is the unique number for that specific area.
subject: Regulations
